block.p: Historic New York Urban Center Galleries of the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 935-3960.

An exhibition of photographs of the Farm Colony-Seaview historic district on Staten Island, which has fallen into disrepair, opened yesterday and will be at the galleries through Sept. 16. The Farm Colony, established as a farm for the poor in 1902, contains Dutch Colonial Revival dormitory and service buildings. The Seaview section was the site of Seaview Hospital, a tuberculosis hospital founded in 1905, and some of the buildings have terra cotta ornaments from Delft, in the Netherlands.
Historic New York Urban Center Galleries of the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 935-3960.

An exhibition of photographs of the Farm Colony-Seaview historic district on Staten Island, which has fallen into disrepair, opened yesterday and will be at the galleries through Sept. 16. The Farm Colony, established as a farm for the poor in 1902, contains Dutch Colonial Revival dormitory and service buildings. The Seaview section was the site of Seaview Hospital, a tuberculosis hospital founded in 1905, and some of the buildings have terra cotta ornaments from Delft, in the Netherlands.
The galleries are open Monday through Saturday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. (closed Thursday). No charge.
Saving One Block Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street; (212) 534-1672.

''Renewing a Block and the Spirit of Its People: Photographs of Carmel Hill, Harlem, by Bill Foley'' is an exhibition of 60 photographs chronicling a reclamation project started in 1992 with the help of the Children's Aid Society and William J. Ruane, a Wall Street fund manager. The black-and-white images, which were taken from 1995 to the present, will be at the museum through Nov. 12.
Open Wednesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Suggested contribution is $7; children, students and those 62 and older, $4; families, $12.
A New Look at Familiar Places 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; (212) 996-1100.

In August, the Y is offering guided tours: the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, on Aug. 6 at 2 p.m.; the Hudson River promenade in Battery Park, on Aug. 13 at 6 p.m.; the Empire State Building, on Aug. 20 at 1 p.m.; and the St. Regis Hotel, on Aug. 20 at 3 p.m. Some tours include refreshments, and participants are invited to bring along a picnic dinner for the Aug. 13 tour. Reservations are required for all events. Fees range from $20 to $60.
Gardens at Rutgers The Rutgers Gardens at Rutgers University, Route 1 and Ryders Lane, New Brunswick, off New Jersey Turnpike exit 9; (732) 932-8451.
An open house will be held on Saturday, from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., with guided tours of the gardens as well as horticultural lectures and events for children. No charge.
